section.title: What is an XML Tree?
section.paragraph: An XML tree, also known as an XML Document Object Model (DOM) tree, is a hierarchical representation of an XML document. It organizes XML data in a parent-child relationship structure, similar to a family tree or an organizational chart.
Every XML document forms a tree structure that starts at the root element and branches to all other elements. The tree structure is called a node-tree.

subsection.title: 1. Root Element
subsection.paragraph: The root element is the topmost element in an XML document. Every XML document must have exactly one root element that contains all other elements.

subsection.title: 2. Parent Elements
subsection.paragraph: A parent element is an element that contains other elements (children). Any element that has sub-elements is considered a parent.

subsection.title: 3. Child Elements
subsection.paragraph: A child element is an element contained within another element (parent). Child elements are nested inside their parent elements.

subsection.title: 4. Sibling Elements
subsection.paragraph: Sibling elements are elements that share the same parent. They exist at the same level in the tree hierarchy.

subsection.title: 5. Leaf Nodes
subsection.paragraph: Leaf nodes (also called terminal nodes) are elements that do not contain any child elements. They typically contain text content or are empty.

section.title: XPath for Tree Navigation
section.paragraph: XPath is a language for navigating XML tree structures. It uses path expressions to select nodes.
